intro: Conyza chilensis var. guaranitica, commonly known as the Guaraní weed, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in Argentina and Paraguay. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and can be found in grasslands and agricultural areas. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it produces small yellow flowers that develop into fluffy, white seed heads. This species is often considered a weed but has been studied for its potential ecological and medicinal properties.
